title.narrative: Women IN Business (WIN) Programme - Inception Phase
Women IN Business (WIN) Programme - Inception Phase

description.narrative:
I enlighet med Beslut om Beredning nr. 48/17, daterat 20170825, fattade ambassaden beslut om att bereda projektet "Women IN Business" baserat på det programförslag som inkommit från TechnoServe. TechnoServe, en internationell enskild organisation verksam i 29 länder, var den organisation av 12 potentiella samarbetsparter, som bäst svarade upp mot den uppdragsbeskrivning som ambassaden inbjöd parterna att lämna förslag programförslag på.En av styrkorna med TechnoServes förslag är möjligheten att utföra en marknads- och värdekedjeanalys, inklusive jämställdhetsanalys, samt test på olika alternativa lösningar för hur kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt kan uppnås innan programmet genomförs i fullskala. Förslaget anses innovativt, holistiskt och skapar förutsättningar för förändring. Vidare bedöms Technoserve ha stor möljighet att genomföra programförslaget effektivt och mer hållbara resultat.
I ovan Beslut om Beredning beslutade ambassaden också att två separata beslut om insatsen kommer att fattas, ett för inledningsfasen - föreslagen insats om 1 år - och ytterligare ett för genomförandet av det fullständiga WIN-programmet på 5 år.
Föreslagen insats avser inledningsfasen och är i linjen med resultaten i strategin för Sveriges utvecklingssamarbete med Mocambique 2015-2020 vilka avser att förbättra möljigheten för människor som lever i fattigdom att bidra och ta del av ekonomisk utveckling och demokratisk samhällsutveckling. Women IN Buiness (WIN) programmet adresserar specifikt strategins resultatområde 3 - "Förbättrade möjligheter och verktyg för fattiga människor att kunna förbättra sina levnadsvillkor" och fokuserar på att uppnå strategiresultat 3.2."Ökad tillgång till tjänster och stöd, i synnerhet för kvinnoroch ungdomar på landsbygden, so förbättrar deras förutsättningar att starta och driva kommersiella verksamheter", samt även delvis strategiresultat 3.1. "Ökade möjligheter för framför allt kvinnor och ungdomar till anständig och produktiv sysselsättning och entreprenörskap". WIN-programmet är i linje med den mocambikiska regeringens femårsstrategi (PQG) 2015-2019 och då specifikt det strategiska målet nummer 5 som avser att verka för ökad jämställdhet, med ett särskilt fokus på kvinnliga entreprenörers ekonomiska egenmakt (informell- och formell sektor).
Insatsen ska framför allt ses som en särskild satsning av ambassaden för att öka och intensifiera profileringen av stöd till kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt, vilket är ett av den svenska strategins huvudmål. WIN-programmet har en bredare ansats till begreppet kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt som både adresserar de ekonomiska och icke-ekonomiska dimensionerna för att uppnå hållbara resultat inom området.
Programmet Women IN Business (WIN) syftar till att öka affärspotentialen hos kvinnoledda mikroföretag, små och medelstora företag (MSMEs) som är verksamma i olika värdekedjor med hög tillväxtpotential i peri-urbana och landsbygdsområden i Moçambique utifrån en marknadsystemansats.
De förväntade resultaten av det fullständiga programmet (inlednings- och genomförandefas) kommer att utformas utifrån de resultat som kommer att uppnås under startfasen. Det specifika målet för inledningsfasen är att genomföra ett antal aktiviteter utifrån en marknadssystemansats. Resultaten av dessa aktiviter kommer att bidra till utvecklingen av det fullständiga programmet (genomförande fasen) och till upprättandet av en övergripande struktur för förvaltning och intern kontroll.
Den totala budgeten för föreslagen insats på ett år uppgår till SEK 8 928 000, vilken finansieras till fullo av Sida. Den planerade budgeten för genomförandefasen uppskattas till omkring 56 500 000 på omkring 5 år.

The Women IN Business (WIN) programme aims to increase business potential of women-led Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) working in value chain with high growth potential in peri-urban and rural areas of Mozambique based in market systems development approach. The program is built upon two phases, inception (this contribution) and implementation with at least 4 years duration.
The overall outcomes of the program are based on the implementation of the entire program, which should be built on the outputs obtained during this contribution (inception phase). The specific objective for the inception phase is to carry out a number of activities with a clear market systems development approach and the obtained results should feed into the development of the future program (implementation phase) and establish an overall structure for management and internal control.

The Women IN Business (WIN) programme aims to increase business potential of women-led Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) working in value chain with high growth potential in peri-urban and rural areas of Mozambique based in market systems development approach. The program is built upon two phases, inception (this contribution), and implementation with at least 4 years duration. The overall outcomes of the program are based on the implementation of the entire program, which should be built on the outputs obtained during this contribution (inception phase). The specific objective for the inception phase is to carry out a number of activities with a clear market systems development approach and the obtained results should feed into the development of the future program (implementation phase) and establish an overall structure for management and internal control. For the inception phase (this contribution) the objective is to obtain outputs in three main areas on which the program (implementation phase) will be constructed around, namely: 1) Diagnostic and confirmation phase through sectoral studies and stakeholder involvement. The core principles for this will be to maximize local stakeholder ownership and collaboration, and sustainability. 2) Programme set up through establishment of partnership with key stakeholders as well as a well-functioning and flexible overall organizational structure. 3) Pilot interventions of the confirmed high growth potential value chains to inform best practice for the planned implementation phase.

tag.narrative: 5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

description.narrative: The inception phase of WIN was focused on program development, team recruitment and training, and partnership building. All the program tools and systems were developed, and five new team members were hired to the program. Program development. TechnoServe developed and submitted a programme document to the Embassy which was approved and granted a funding of SEK 56,500,000 for a further four years of program implementation 2019 - 2022. Following a period of more in-depth research and external review, the programme made some revisions to its overall theory of change and sector definitions and validated the project’s goals and targets. The main change is that WIN is now considering micro-entrepreneurship under a single theory of change, rather than separating industry verticals. This is because, first, WIN found that many of the challenges facing micro-entrepreneurs are not specific to the industry or activity of the entrepreneur, and second, due to the thin markets in Mozambique, we do not want to restrict the areas and opportunities that WIN can work in. WIN will consider whether to open a second sector based on employment of low-income women, depending on the progress made in micro-entrepreneurship. WIN has submitted a revised program document to take account of these changes. Team recruitment and training. WIN went through a capacity building in areas such as research, idea generation, partnership development, monitoring and reporting. This comprised intensive MSD training week and invited a number of other partners and practitioners to attend a “market systems master class”. This led to the developmentof a “MSD network”, which meet bimonthly to discuss approaches and findings, and is improving communication and resources among market systems programs in Mozambique. This “MSD network” is first in its kind and was an unexpected positive result of WIN Inception. Partnership building and piloting. WIN was able to complete a more detailed design of interventions in prioritised sectors and began a more detailed research into both the textiles and garments and the trade sectors. As a result of this effort, WIN was able to prioritise three interventions to take forward with partners – one focused on sewing machine access, one to pilot artisanal production of textiles, and another on cold storage equipment. The sewing machine area started to be piloted. The example of results achieved by WIN Inception programme are provided below. They are more activity and outout based which is line with Inception phase activities (recruitment of the management team, design the main documents to operationalise the programme, training of the core team). 1. Design a program-wide strategy and templates for knowledge and results management. WIN produced revised strategies for the programme as a whole, and for the sub-areas of trade, and textiles and garments. WIN produced templates for intervention strategies and intervention guides (including M&E) and set up the Decision Unit. It has a shared drive with all knowledge and results clearly recorded and labelled by intervention. WIN also developed its gender strategy and approach. Lastly, WIN developed an intervention tracker and detailed work plan for continuous monitoring of program activities internally. 2. Detailed design and start intervention(s) in the first sector. WIN conducted further research in the textiles and garments sector, visiting garment-makers, customers and industry representatives in each of Beira, Nampula and Maputo. As a result, it developed a revised strategy for this sub-sector, which prioritized interventions based on feasibility and impact. WIN signed a partnership agreement with Bernina and has started the intervention to set up a franchise and/or incubator. WIN also agreed a partnership with Deolinda Rodrigues (wholesaler) and has begun work to help her open up her cold storage to the women micro-retailers. 3. Research and feasibility checks around new sectors – trade and childcare. The decision was taken to pursue opportunities in trade sub-sector. Further research was conducted, with the team visiting markets and producers in and around Maputo, Nampula and Beira to understand more about the market traders. WIN also commissioned a study by ICC on market retailers in Fajardo market in Maputo, to better understand their constraints and validate the idea of an intervention in the area of cold storage. As a result of the research, a strategy and intervention prioritization was developed. 4. External independent review. An external reviewer conducted an assessment in December / January. This led to a session on objectives clarification (advised by the reviewer) and the revision of the programme document and sector definitions. 5. Design website and program collateral. A draft of the program website and collateral is under development and will be launched in the coming weeks, along with the program logo.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
